page.title: 13Types of Housing in St.Agnes
page.content: Many of the old cottages are built of cob, a mixture of clay and straw that makes very thick walls. These make very warm buildings. A few still have thatched roofs, but these are now a minority. Many new housing estates have sprung up in recent years - the newer houses being built of breezeblock. Bungalows abound - mostly two or three bedroomed to accommodate the smaller families. Council estates house a large number of people in small but compact houses - semi-detached, rather than terraced. The farmhouses are built of stone and are very solid. The Cornish hedge usually encloses the gardens. Hotels and Guest houses are constructed of stone, and in some of the older types Cornish granite has been incorporated to form the doorways and steps.
